questions.text: A 22-Year-old primigravida female was due for her date and started having labor pain at 8 am. On examination, PV findings revealed – cervical dilatation - 6 cm, 70% effaced, membranes intact. 2 hours after full cervical dilatation, the fetus is not delivered. She is exhausted, and on PV, caput formation can be felt. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Normal vaginal delivery with the help of vacuum extraction

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate C-section In the given case, the female is having second-stage arrest . Hence we should actively manage this patient and immediately do a C-section.

Highyeild:

AVERAGE PROLONGED SECOND STAGE ARREST PRIMI: 50 minutes PRIMI: > 2 hours PRIMI: > 3 hours MULTI: 20 minutes MULTI: > 1 hour MULTI: > 2 hours

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Wait and watch is a blunder in this patient as the patient has a second-stage arrest. Hence expected delivery won't be possible. Option: C. Vaginal delivery by forceps or vacuum extraction is not done in case of second-stage arrest. Option: D. Sedation and therapeutic rest in advance labor are not helpful but rather dangerous for both mother and fetus.

Extraedge:

If an epidural is given, the above-mentioned values will increase by an hour.

questions.text: A 20-Year-old G1 at 41 weeks has been pushing for 2½ hours. The fetal head is at the introitus and beginning to crown. It is necessary to have an episiotomy. The tear extends through the sphincter of the rectum, but the rectal mucosa is intact. How should you classify this type of episiotomy tear?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Third-degree In a third-degree tear, the rectal sphincter is affected.

Highyeild:

Grade 1: Skin is cut Grade 2: Skin + Muscle cut Grade 3A: <50% EAS involved Grade 3B: >50% EAS involved Grade 3C: Anal sphincter + EAS involved Grade 4: Rectal mucosa involved

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. First-degree tear involves the vaginal mucosa or perineal skin, not the underlying tissue. Option: B. In a second-degree episiotomy, the underlying subcutaneous tissue is also involved, not the rectal sphincter or rectal mucosa. Option: D. A fourth-degree episiotomy involves a tear that extends into the rectal mucosa. It should be repaired immediately in OT.

Extraedge:

If a complete perineal tear happened two weeks ago , the repair is done after three months.

questions.text: A 24-Year-old nulliparous female with an onset of labor pain at noon was admitted. P/V done at 8 pm showed the cervix fully dilated and effaced, membranes ruptured, and the head station is +3. Even after 1 hour, there is no delivery of the head of the fetus. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Take the patient for a C-section

options.label: C
options.text: Normal vaginal delivery without any aids

options.label: D
options.text: Give IV oxytocin infusion for augmentation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vacuum-assisted delivery The clinical picture depicts a prolonged second stage of labor for the nullipara in the given question. Hence the management depends on the station of the fetal head . As the station is +3, the next step will be delivering with the help of a vacuum.

Highyeild:

AVERAGE PROLONGED SECOND STAGE ARREST PRIMI: 50 minutes PRIMI: > 2 hours PRIMI: > 3 hours MULTI: 20 minutes MULTI: > 1 hour MULTI: > 2 hours

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. C-Section is required in case of second-stage arrest. Option: C . As the second stage of labor is prolonged, we should intervene and deliver with the help of aids like forceps or vacuum. Option: D. IV oxytocin infusion for augmentation is required in the first phase of the labor. Here oxytocin only will not be of much help.

Extraedge:

If the head is palpable, PA : Forceps/Vacuum delivery cannot be done.

questions.text: A nulliparous woman is in active labor (cervical dilation 5 cm with complete effacement, vertex at 0 stations); the labor curve shows protracted progression without descent following the administration of an epidural block. An IUPC shows contractions every 4 to 5 minutes, peaking at 40 mm Hg. How would you proceed further?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxytocin intravenously Options A, C & D are false. This protracted labor is associated with hypotonic uterine dysfunction , a condition that the epidural block may have exacerbated. If not contraindicated by other factors (e.g., uterine scar), augmentation of labor by intravenous oxytocin is the treatment of choice.

Highyeild:

Augmentation is done when the pregnant female is already in labor, but the process is slow. Acceleration is done by giving oxytocin, artificial rupture of membranes (PGE2 is released). Dose = 10 IU I.M or I.V infusion

Extraedge:

Oxytocin is never given as an IV bolus as it can cause hypotension and cardiac arrest. t ½ = 3-5 minutes

questions.text: A primipara is in the second stage of labor, and an episiotomy is about to be cut. Compared with a midline episiotomy, which of the following is an advantage of mediolateral episiotomy?
questions.correct_answer: D. Less extension of the incision.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Less extension of the incision. Risks of an episiotomy include: ‌ Bleeding A longer healing time Complications for future vaginal deliveries Dyspareunia Pelvic floor issues Urinary fistulas Visible scars or internal scar tissue that is painful

Highyeild:

Midline episiotomies are easier to fix and have a smaller incidence of surgical breakdown, less pain, and lower blood loss. The incidence of dyspareunia is somewhat less. However, the incidence of extensions of the incision to include the rectum is considerably higher than with mediolateral episiotomies.

questions.text: A woman at 32 weeks of pregnancy presents with labor pains. On examination, her cervix is dilated, and uterine contractions are felt. The management is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isoxsuprine hydrochloride Patient is presenting at 32 weeks (i.e., third trimester) with cervix dilated and uterine contractions are felt, which indicates it is a case of early preterm labor and should be managed by giving tocolytic i.e. isoxsuprine hydrochloride. The tocolytic will delay labor by 48 hours . In the meanwhile, we will give corticosteroids , so that the lung of the fetus matures.

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut while using the following instrument, except:

options.label: B
options.text: Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anal sphincter Options A, B & C are cut. The image shows episiotomy scissors.

Highyeild:

The following structures are cut during episiotomy: 1. Posterior vaginal wall 2. Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles 3. Bulbospongiosus (option d not bulbocavernosus) 4. Part of Levator ani 5. Fascia covering those muscles 6. Transverse perineal branches of pudenda, vessels, and nerves 7. Subcutaneous tissue and skin

questions.correct_answer: B. After full dilatation of cervix
questions.explanation:
Solution:

After full dilatation of cervix Membranes usually rupture after full dilatation of the cervix or sometimes even beyond, in the second stage.

Highyeild:

Early Rupture of Membranes: Rupture of membranes any time after the onset of labor but before full dilatation of the cervix. Premature Rupture of Membrane: Rupture of membranes before the onset of labor. Sometimes the membranes remain intact until the completion of delivery; the fetus is then born surrounded by them.

questions.text: Which is not included in active management of 3rd stage in labor to prevent PPH?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct oxytocin injection after delivery of shoulder

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate cutting and cord clamping
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate cutting and cord clamping

Highyeild:

Active management of the third stage of labor includes: (i) Administration of a uterotonic soon after birth (best is oxytocin followed by methergine. (ii) Delayed cord clamping. (iii) Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction. (iv) Uterine massage. Early cord clamping is being discouraged because if the cord is clamped immediately, the cord blood present in it (80-100 ml) will go to waste whereas, if delayed cord clamping is done, the cord blood goes to the newborn. There are fewer chances of anemia, intraventricular hemorrhage, and late-onset sepsis especially in preterm infants.

questions.text: You are a final year MBBS student undergoing an obs final examination. You are asked about the safe practices that can be performed while delivering the head of the fetus. You will mention all the points except

options.label: A
options.text: To perform timely episiotomy when indicated

options.label: B
options.text: Delivery of the head by early extension reduces the chances of perineal laceration.

options.label: C
options.text: To apply warm compresses to the perineum

options.label: D
options.text: To deliver the head in between the contractions.

questions.correct_answer: B. Delivery of the head by early extension reduces the chances of perineal laceration.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delivery of the head by early extension reduces the chances of perineal laceration. Delivery by early extension is to be avoided.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Episiotomy need not be performed universally. It is performed when indicated. Option: C. Warm compresses can be applied to the perineum to provide relief to the women. Option: D. Head of the baby should be delivered between the contractions.
